name: Convolver
description: This algorithm performs real-time convolution of the input signal and another signal (often called an 'impulse response'), which is loaded from the MicroSD card. Convolution is a technique used for realistic reverb effects by sampling impulse responses from physical locations, but it can also be applied creatively to mangle and combine sounds. The disting NT is a resource-constrained embedded system, so this algorithm will not achieve the same results as high-end convolution reverbs in DAWs with more CPU power and RAM. However, it remains useful within modular synthesis contexts.
use_cases: Realistic reverb effects using impulse responses sampled from physical spaces
Creative sound mangling and combination via convolution
Master bus insert effect for adding reverb to entire mixes (with long latency tolerance)
Loading impulse responses from MicroSD card for real-time processing
gui_description: The display shows a graphical representation of the impulse sample on the left. On the right, it displays the mono/stereo processing mode, maximum impulse time based on current parameters, actual length of the loaded sample file, and overall CPU usage.

specifications.name: Sample rate
specifications.description: All disting NT algorithms run at a fixed sample rate of 48kHz. The 'Sample rate' parameter allows internal downsampling to lower rates (48kHz, 24kHz, 12kHz, or 6kHz) for longer impulse times but reduced audio bandwidth.

specifications.name: Max impulse length
specifications.description: The maximum length of the impulse response sample that can be processed depends on allocated memory, mono/stereo mode, latency settings, and internal downsampling. Longer impulses are generally desirable for reverb applications.

specifications.name: CPU usage
specifications.description: Convolution is notoriously CPU-intensive. The disting NT's limited resources mean the algorithm will not perform as efficiently as high-end convolution reverbs in DAWs, but it remains functional within modular synthesis constraints.

specifications.name: Latency options
specifications.description: The algorithm processes audio in blocks. Latency can be adjusted to balance between lower latency (shorter impulse times) and higher latency (longer impulse times). Dry signal remains synced with convolution output regardless of latency.

specifications.name: Memory allocation
specifications.description: More allocated memory allows longer impulse responses to be processed, at the cost of available resources for other algorithms or tasks.

input_ports.name: Left/mono input
input_ports.description: The left or mono audio input bus (1-28).

input_ports.name: Right input
input_ports.description: The right audio input bus (0-28, 0 means no signal).

output_ports.name: Right output
output_ports.description: The right audio output bus (0-28, 0 means no signal).
